												Having played for just over an hour now here's what I have to say about the game. If you ever played Port of Call, Transocean - The Shipping Company is a modern version of that. Everything from the time progression to "status" or "reputation" to unlock more ships.  There are some nice features of the sim that are handy to use such as the financial statements & diagrams, also the ability to take out loans is great as well. I didn't bother playing the campaign, just went right into the free play. After about 20-30 minutes of contracting out my small feed ship i unlocked all the ports of europe, thereafter I unlocked the entire world. I gained enough capital to purchase some bigger pre-panamax ships and began trading the lucrative routes.  Graphics wise the sim is pleasing to the eyes, beautiful colors, non-cluttered interface, lots to look at without getting bombarded with useless information. There isn't a real challenging component to free play that I observed, eventually your larger vessels experience massive profit margins. If you complete a contract for 30 million euros, your fuel costs will only be about 5% of that, which is fine I guess, but I have a feeling that real shippers experience much more turbulent expenses. I'm not complaining, just, thinking out loud. Anyways, this sim is shouting for tankers & drybulker vessels, stock market simulation, buyouts, further player interaction with other AI shipping companies (or even other players!) I hope Deck13 doesn't simply abandon this just yet. Oh and wait, there is more.Many of you know the embarressing and disasterous repuation that German devs/publishing firms have for releasing unfinished products then abandoning them, i must say within the hour of playing, I didnt crash once, experience a bug or anything like that. It was flawless. Congrats! Anyways I'll swing a 8/10 would play again. Thanks.

												Everybody look at me 'cause I'm sailin' on a boat!After two hours of play, I have to say that I'm impressed.  After just a couple tutorial missions (each and all skippable in turn), I was turned loose to make or break my company.  After a few lucrative ore contracts, I found myself smuggling contraband on the Mediterranian.  And got busted.  And my cargo seized.  And fined.  And my ship impounded for a week.  A time-based contract I still had in the hold expired, so there were penalties there.  And harbor masters didn't care to allow convicted smuggers in their ports, so harbor fees went up.  All that in two hours and not a moment that felt repeatative.A few features that I liked:  Your home port determines what bonuses your company gets.  I picked Lisbon for +5% on ore contracts and -10% to fuel.  The trick is, the smaller the port, the larger the bonuses.  So you have a reason to keep smaller ports and the ships that can service them.There is some ship customization.  The Feeder I started with had three levels of Hull and Engine upgrades, which increased range and speed respectively.  There was also a license upgrade that would allow me to carrry what appeared to be hazardous waste.  Unfortunately, there does not appear to be options for custom paint or appearance (other than your ship name emblazoned upon the stern and bow).I remember reading a comment somewhere saying that the music was repeatative and annoying.  To me, it sounded like every port had it's own song.  And each port felt VERY unique.  I'm already developing favorites and least favorites.The only meh item I encountered dealt with other ship traffic.  Large ships move fast and looked intimidating at first, but it turns out they can stop on a dime and give the player right-of-way.  I would have liked to have seen navigation lights and right-of-way implemented (and fines for failure to obey maritime traffic laws).Anyway, back to my ship.  I'm saving up for a fleet.  And I'm naming all my vessels after internet porn sites.

												This is a cool game and all but it has its negatives that quickly spoil the experience.First, docking and undocking is tedious as hell and gets very old very quickly. Unfortunately you're essentially required to do it every time, since using a tugboat is $100K a pop -- so docking and undocking at any given port if you don't want to deal with this tedious docking mechanic is $200k. When you're starting out and your profit margins are very thin this isn't feasible.Second, in the campaign your investor is essentially the villain. Every quarter she takes what seems like half of your cash and when you finally scrape up enough to rank up to the next size ship she saddles you with an impossible contract which requires you to ship an insane amount of goods to a specific port (including things that you can't even ship yet without ship upgrades that you can't buy) or lose $10M. Guess when this automatically kicks off? When you hit $10M in cash. Oh the best part? You have around a month to deliver everything. Twice. Twice I hit this point and this impossible burden combined with the investor taking her quarterly cut left me bankrupt. I would keep trying but the aforementioned docking mechanic saps my will to start over.Third, the sailing mechanic isn't very deep. When your ships are sailing you'll get popups like "there's a storm a comin" and it asks you if you want to sail around it or sail through. I can't tell the difference between the two aside from the fact that sailing through practically destroys your ship. This is fine, but if a game is going to abstract this sort of thing but then require you to micromanage things like docking it seems a little schizophrenic.Take these three things and it turns out to be a game that is profoundly unfun which is a shame because it's the first thing that really ruins it. Slashing towing fees would go a long way to making the game better.

												Recommended, but ONLY if, like me, you played Ports of Call on a dodgy DOS computer and couldn't get enough of expanding your fleet. As that is not likely to be the majority, I am not recommending it.This game IS Ports of Call, there are a few additions and subtractions but the core of it is simple: Get the most out of your fleet. However, where PoC offered depth and complexity, in this it isn't difficult to achieve what you want to achieve, it is a fun(ish) time-waster for a few hours before you realise it is severely hampered by lack of depth. It is PoC but done half-hearted at points where it matters. I've just sent two ships off from New York to Algiers, loaded with medicine, to finish a contract off. Both ships for some mysterious reason left without their loads. In PoC I would turn them round and ignore the bug, here you can't: You cast-off, that is it.In PoC part of the minigames was that you would manoeuver the ship in tricky situations, ice, reefs, castaways. Here you either damage your ship or have to wait for an unknown time. I am fine with the minigame element being gone, but now I haven't got a clue what determines how long you wait, it doesn't tell you (unlike PoC), but having a ship sail "round a reef" just of the Galician coast and it taking 12 days... It could have been in the Antarctic by that time. Some of these aspects feel like they've just been put in to slow down the player for no apparent reason. The game is a lot easier. The upgrades to ships are a potentially nice addition, but instead are a sure-fire way to rolling in cash in no time. Once you unlock radioactive goods and weapons, you rake in the cash. I feel there is a massive missed opportunity here. They've introduced a reputation system, why not link it to that? Other goods are already linked to it, also - gaining rep should be A LOT harder, now it is linked to being on time a lot, which is the easiest thing to achieve, it should be linked to the state of your ships, quality of your crew-training, quality and quantity of subsidiaries, average cost per TEU. Reputation in turn should determine the quality of the contracts you can achieve, you begin hauling fish from Iceland to Germany for a few years, after demonstrating you can do that and keep your ship in good condition, you might get the opportunity to bid for another contract and so on. This game COULD have been a brilliant and legit successor to the PoC throne, what it should have done was offer MORE depth, not less. The new additions really don't help and the fact that management of the fleet is now so simplified reduces its value even more. Instead of putting different goods-types central it should have gone down the route of: Container-ships/Bulk-carriers and contract-work only, you know, like the real world? It should have an AI, also bidding on contracts. Real life margins in this business are cut-throat, yet after playing a few hours in the sandbox on medium difficulty I have 15 top of the range ships and billions of dollars to instantly expand my fleet - but there is no reason to. All I do now is send ships from one radio-active port to another and rake in the cash.  Real shame as it is a huge missed opportunity. Sims become great when they have more depth, not less. Look at Paradox games for an example of how to get that right.

												OK, this review is primarily for the campaign game as I still am in the progress of completing it.THE GOOD:If you remember Ports Of Call, this game has a very familiar feel to it.  So much so that I would consider it the spiritual successor to that fine game.  The ship docking is nearly identical, smaller feeder ships are more difficult to dock than the larger post panamax & larger ships that have side streamer jets that will allow much better maneuverability than the tiny ships.  Many varied ports are available worldwide to sail into and each port has very unique feel to it.  Hamburg & Santos are especially technical and can be quite challenging and fun to sail into at full speed.  They have an option to pay a tug to skip the manual docking for a fee based on your ship size.  The fee can be quite a hit to the profitability of the runs... Which leads me to the Bad...THE BAD:Profitability:  I have noticed that the smaller ships, while they carry much less cargo, and in some cases are significantly slower, are FAR more profitable than the larger ships.  Cargoes are 3 to 5 times more profitable per container than the larger ships.  THIS IS A COLOSSAL FLAW IMO, and a huge reason that my fleet of over 200 post panamax ships is starting to bog down my computer.  I refuse to make runs where the cargo value for my huge UCLV ship is equal to a post panamax ship 3 size classes smaller.I have found that there are ways to crock the game model by leaving feeder ships in the company contract ports to generate hordes of tiny highly profitable contracts meant for feeder ships, but this exploit should not be needed.  The value of the cargo should remain similar through all the ship classes to motivate players to want to get the giant ships (which are a blast to drive) because they are big money as well as big fun.  Instead I am forced to slog through thousands of port tug fees to remain profitable.  Which leads me to the UGLY...THE UGLY:  The worst part of the campaign is the outright thievery of the investor.  The first several status upgrades come along at reasonable intervals and have logical milestones to nudge the player to create a shipping empire.  Once the player hits the Magnate level though, the game bogs down into mindnumbing repetition.  The game becomes a treadmill of completing company contract after company contract.  The fun "quests" of filling a whole slew of varied contracts to a specific city are no more.  The "driving quests" where you are tasked with parking several of each ship are gone.Tycoon level is the worst though.  Your only goal is to gather enough money to buy out this thief, who wants roughly triple the value of your empire when you hit Tycoon.  That wouldn't be so bad if I hadn't spent the entirety of the game building up a world spanning empire.  The main problem is that the thief/investor comes in every 3 months and steals 25% of your cash!  This game mechanic alone is almost enough to stop even the most diehard players in their tracks.  I have found that after a point, it becomes nigh impossible to break through this crock of a game mechanic and actually succeed and "win" the game.All in all I would give a thumbs up to the game as a whole, but not the campaign.  While the campaign starts out great, it ends like the Hindenburg explosion...  OH THE HUMANITY of repetition!  I have read the previews for Transocean 2, and multiplayer mode sounds like great fun. For now though, I have to agree with may other reviewers.  Grab the game on sale, and enjoy it.  Very likely it will be cheaper per hour of entertainment  than a movie, and when you create your own conditions for victory, the non-campaign could be quite enjoyable indeed.

												This is the first game I purchased via the Steam recommendations.  I am certainly not disappointed.  So far, I have 10 hours in the game, and I feel addicted.  This is a fairly simple simulator/logistics game.  The game has a tutorial, and I'm playing through it.  However, if you played similar games, such as Cities in Motion or Railroad Tycoon, then you can probably figure this out.  You buy a ship, get a contract, and then deliver the goods.  You have investors, you can take out a loan, and your ship will need fuel and maintenance.  From that standpoint, it is very easy.  As you get more ships, you gain more capacity but lose some capability.  Eventually, you can create company specific contracts that require delivery of a certain good to a certain location; at this point the complexity starts to become apparent.  To keep it interesting, you also have to deal with storms, pirates, and fires at sea.While the game is fun to play, it still needs some polish.  I've had a few popup notifications remain on the screen.  I can play through them and sometimes get them to disappear, but its a bug.  While there are hazards, like storms and pirates, they purely random rather location specific, thus avoidable.  For example, I had a piracy near the Canaries, and I hit a storm with one vessel while another vessel sailed through the same area at the same time without the storm.  Personally, I find these oddities to be minor imperfections and potential room for growth in the development.  Overall the game is very solid platform and is good enough for this early release.A larger area for growth is the games focus on cargo container shipping.  I commented about this in relation to US ports on the forums.  I was happy to see the game designer respond within hours of my comments.  While my request won't go fulfilled for now, I'm satisfied knowing that they understand the issue.I'm definitely getting my money's worth from the game.  I think the game is playable for most ages.  If you are into sims like this, you'll love it.  If you prefer FPS games, then you'll probably hate this game as it is not meant for you.  I recommend this to all the simmers out there.

												I missed seeing this game when it came out, or I would have gotten it sooner, It is a simple cargo ship company tycoon game, very much like the classic 1986 Ports Of Call, with lovely 3D graphics and overall a nicer art style. For those interested, Ports Of Call XXL is in development (www.portsofcall.de), and you can get versions of the classic game as well. http://www.metallicat95.com/?p=388 -- my review pageTransOcean has all the nice elements for a trading game — transport cargo from port to port, trying to make the most money and boost your reputations in order to improve your shipping company. Travel to more ports, play the ship driving minigame to get in and out of the docks for more status (and to save money and see the nice scenery), buy more ships, complete company contracts, and get rich. Or go bankrupt if you fail, but the game is overall fairly easy to play.This is a single player game, with a sequel with multiplayer and more features coming out in May 2016, As such, my recommendation is to get this one on sale, unless you can’t wait to get your ship captain fix now. The polish of this game is a good sign for the future of its replacement, and I expect that you won’t get exactly the same sort of challenges and game play features in the sequel.  This original game does, though, contain the background story and missions which set up the campaign mode of its sequel, and may be a little easier to play (in single player).There are two basic game modes, the campaign — a mission-driven game with an investor who gives you orders and wants to be paid back, with the ultimate goal to become a tycoon and take control of the company — and the free game, where you just run the shipping company however you want. The campaign can be a challenge to win, but also provides a nice tutorial on how to play.Much of the joy of the game is making smart choices and watching your company and bank balance grow. You will spend most of your time watching your ships sail around the world, and making decisions when they reach ports. Refuel now, or wait for a cheaper location? Select cargos for the best pay, but take into account the chances of getting new valuable jobs at each destination. Repair or upgrade your ship as needed. Some cargos require upgrades in order to legally carry them — take them without and you risk customs inspections and fines. Time spent sitting in port costs money, so that is another hard choice.Some jobs have time deadlines. They pay better, increase your status if you are one time, but penalize you if you fail. The company contracts you can take give you a mission to deliver a specific kind of cargo from one specific port to another, with a time limit as well. They add another piece of depth, trading guaranteed work with a good payoff at the end (and more status) for a commitment which makes you miss out on valuable high-paying loads to other locations — or taking them, and risk failing the contract.All the ships in this game are container cargo ships, and can carry multiple cargo loads as long as they fit on the ship. Sometimes you have enough to fill the ship and go to one destination, but often you must it several destinations in order to travel fully loaded. Each port docked at takes time and money.Early in the game, you will dock manually and play a simple ship driving game to get into or out of the harbor. It isn’t hard to do being slow and patient, but most of us don’t want to wait too long, and so you take chances and risk damaging your ship. Succeeding boosts your status. Being Famous means you’ll get better deals and cargos than a small, Unknown company and captain.Later in the game, especially once you’ve seen all the ports in 3D, you’ll just pay the tug costs and skip this part of the game, as long as you have the money in the bank.There are dangers which can affect your ship’s travel — storms at sea, fires, sickness, reefs, pirates, rescue missions — plus the risk of customs delays if your ship isn’t running legally. Taking the risky illegal goods (counterfeit and questionable merchandise) pays very well, but has much higher fines and delays if you are caught. Plus the illegal goods are confiscated, unlike loads where you aren’t compliant with regulations.Most trips, though, are uneventful for legal, properly maintained ships. You’ll spend your time making good choices each time a ship hits port, and when you cast off to send it to its next destination. The game proceeds in simulated real time (you can accelerate the clock, and will do so often in the early game). With more ships in play, you will have a lot on your mind, as you try to figure out the best way to make money and complete your missions.The sequel adds competition -- AI and human multiplayer -- and expands a lot on this game.  But the basic elements seem similar enough, with, I hope, enough improvements to make it a really great game to enjoy with friends.

												My review is from single player only. I work for a container shipping company, so this game caught my eye a while ago. I expected something like the classic Railroad Tycoon series, but with ships. What I got was something different, but in a bad way. The game itself isn't horrid, but more something that is vastly inefficient. The mini-game of docking the ships manually when they call ports is tedious and just isn't worth it at almost any point in the game. The whole thing is pointless. The business element is very lacking, and I was disappointed that the one of only ways they could think to make the game challenging was to vary the same starting scenario. The only thing that changes is the insane interest rate the player is required to pay to the angel investor, along with her ability to sign annoying shipping contracts with huge penalties without your consent. Starting capital should be something the player is in conrol of, or at least given some options. I haven't beaten the game yet, but so far the only risk is getting caught without proper liscense to carry goods and varying interest rates. All of the systematic risks associated with shipping, storms, fire, whatever are all completely random and don't even affect other ships on the same rotues. There is no political risk, market risk, exchange rate risk, or purchasing power risk. The game is supposed to be global, but has nothing global about the simulated economy nor is it dynamic in supply/demand. Last, and probably the biggest deal breaker, I don't enjoy the micro management required in this game. Having to approve every single ship when you call port is annoying, and it seems almost impossible to set up a static voyage using supply and demand or contracts. Every port you have to pick new goods based on what is available and then decide where the ship is to go next, and because goods cant be transferred at ports for a hub and spoke strategy, the only way to play is by having direct routes for every ship. In late game, you have so many shipts they are calling ports every 4 seconds so the gameplay never feels like it is going anywhere. Youre costantly being inturruped by having to agree to pay the docking fee, load more goods, and then choose the next port. The only way to keep ships in specific areas is to basically micromanage contracts, and have them sit in port waiting for a contract that keeps them from having to go from the EU to Asia, or float them completely empty to another port, which is again heavy micromanagement when you consider how many ships you have to track in late game, and not realistic at all.These business simulators still have things to learn, and it makes you truely appreciate games which are very well done like the Railroad Tycoon seres. They are still amazing. The next installment of Transcean is out this summer, I hope it is a little better.

												Simply put its a great game, if you are interested in a game that is all about managing a network of ships, ensuring you can afford the ships, fuel, repairs and any fines you incure all the while needing to keep enough money in the bank to pay your greedy investor then this may be the game for you.The graphics are exactly what you would expect from a game that is essentialy a map and a bunch of finance screens, simple clean and easy to understand. The docking part of the game is quite fun but when you have 10+ ships can become very tedious to dock every ship. The advantage of actually docking yourself is you save the moring fee's and when it come to the most expensive ship in the game thats a lot of money especialy if you dock the ship and leave the port. So it comes in handy throughout the game and while you dont need to use it ever it can be useful (especialy if your ships is empty and you need to move to a different port and want to save some money), its also quite fun and challenging as some of the docks are very oddly shapped and possitioned. The graphics for the docking are nice clean and I expect will stand the test of time nicely.Every aspect of the game is fun, if a bit repetative, however with the docking mini game you can vary it up and keep the fun alive. It does become very repetative nearing the end of the game as you are simply trying to buy out your investor and the money you need is huge and can take a little too long to reach, which is the only real downside to this entire game. I wold have liked to have seen a few other elements like competiton with other companies and the such but alas not in this game. If the game starts to feel repetative try taking on a contract that is restrictive or try and get a chain of contracts, there are many ways to keep your interest, you just need to look for them.The tutorial is very good and is perfectly integrated into the main game so no need to stop and start. You follow the instructions and you start making money. My personal recomendayion is to always but the ship with the highest top speed and bigest hold, the distance it can travel is imaterial, especialy when you reach level 3 and 4 ships.Pro'sGraphics are simple and clean and will not feel dated in the years to comeA number of different challenges throughout the game.Piloting the ships are fun and challenging, the latter ships with thrusters, makes piloting a dream.Finding the best routes to make money is a lot of fun.Con'sCan be repetative, especialy later on.You will hate how much the investor takes from you and can be annoying when you simply want to finish the game.Becomes a little to easy in the late game.When you have 15 + ships it still takes forever to buy out the investorConclusion, this is a fun game that will keep you occupied for many hours, however its not for everyone and you need to be a tycoon fan to get the most out of this game, and even then trying to end the game will annoy you.

												I would totally love to recommend this game, but I just cant because of a few issues:1. You start the campaign with little money (how suprising) and to maximize the profits of your contracts you are forced to manually dock into the harbors. This is okay for a few times but will soon get boring. The automatic tug-in feature costs additional money depending on the ship class. Therefore you have to dock manually to get faster to better ships. With those you can easily pay the additional fee, but at the start you cant afford that and have to do the docking by yourself for the first 1.5-2h of the game.2. After you reached the 2nd ship class the world map opens and you can take contracts to cross the oceans. Your advisor tells you, that the starting ship class (the "Feeder"-class) is not able to carry enough to make such trips profitable.You may think "Okay, then I use the Feeders to only ship goods within a continent." .. Yes, but no. The number of contracts which lets you do this is very limited when the world map opens up. Most contracts are intercontinental from now on.This makes the "Feeder" quite useless. He cant carry much weight, is very slow and cant deliver all goods because he cant be upgraded to do so. Compared to the bigger ships, the "Feeder" is a deadweight to your company. But only the "Feeder" is able to dock at small harbors like Reykjavik or Anchorage which leads to the most concerning point:3. After a while the stakeholder of your company signs contracts for you. If you dont manage to fulfill these you have to pay a penalty fee. I am okay with this but some contracts require you to use "Feeders" since you have to sail to the smaller harbors. So.. the game tells you that "Feeders" are useless in the later stages, but forces you to keep them. At some point you get a contract where you are told, that if you dont fulfill it, the stakeholder closes your company. And guess what: You need "Feeders" to reach the smaller harbors.Additionally to this illogical design.. why would a stakeholder close a company which is highly profitable and granted him like 2000% interests of the initial investment?This was the point at which I stoped playing.I would really like to recommend this (I love Port Royal, Patrician and Rise of Venice), but these issues just ruined the whole experience for me.

There are still minor bugs, but I haven't run into anything game-breaking or that couldn't be resolved without a quick restart.The docking/undocking minigame is a fun diversion that lets you see the beautiful port cities. As some have mentioned the camera angle is somewhat limited denying you a full panorama, but it's not too terrible. You can zoom out further once you unlock bigger ships, but the camera is locked between about 45 degrees and straight top-down.The rest of the game is pretty well balanced. There are some random events that provide enough risk/reward to gamble on transporting illegal goods for example, or good you don't own a license for. Sometimes you can get away with it and sometimes customs will seize your haul and hit you with a big fine.It still remains profitable to keep your starter ships as well. Your $/ton scales depending on the size ship you have. Smaller ships have the highest $/ton while the largest have the smallest, making up for it in sheer bulk.The campaign puts a progression track in while putting a wrench in the gears every so often to keep things interesting. You will get contracts you were forced to agree to from time to time that have a tight deadline and require a great deal of coordination to pull off.Overall, a very polished experience in this genre, and I would highly recommend it if you're a fan of the genre already. If you are a new player, give it a try. If you don't find your zen playing this type of repetitive game, this genre may not be for you, and that's ok!

												TransOcean is a great management game with surprisingly addictive gameplay, trying to manage each ship as it sails across the globe is fun and being able to dock manually both breaks up the monotony and serves as an interesting gameplay mechanic (free docking) the game does have it's flaws though. While each port is beautifully rendered, they are poorly designed, often forcing ships to take odd routes, without a tug or bow/stern thrusters your ships are sometimes forced to take extra long routes or to take damage while docking or undocking; they also often have inconveniently placed obstacles like islands and landmarks, which wouldn't be so bad if the ships felt right. The ships feel like they slide around far to much, it's almost like they're turning from a point far forward of the actual rudder of the ship, additionally the top speed is 10 knots, less than 20 miles per hour, but looks to be about 100 miles per hour. All in all they just feel wrong and if they were tweaked a little would feel much better.These facts are by no means dealbreakers, and the game is fantastic even with them. If I was to suggest some changes; in addition to fixing up the ship handling (turning should be tighter, speed should feel lower and all ships should have thrusters) and the port design; I would find a way to spice up the map view a bit, it's quite dull at the moment. I would also prefer some adjustments to how the map works, clicking ports in Europe can sometimes be a challenge once the full map opens up since the game never remembers your zoom level and the ports in Europe are so close. The map outside of Europe also feels quite empty, with very limited options in North and South America.Hopefully this review doesn't sound too negative, but I find that negative points are often more useful in deciding if I want something or not. I recommend this game fully as a solid entry into any managment game fan's library.

												Yes, I would recommend......to fans of turn-based empire managment simulations that also have an interest in sea-borne commerce and merchant marine.>|< Quantatitive Rating = 7 out of 10 >|<______________________________Observations and other musings...This game is a lot like any management game, like space empire building without the conflict of war. In this case your focus is on fleet building and freight management. They have put in a lot of antagonist elements that take the place of conflict-based issues of other games, like an investor that you have to buy out eventually, otherwise the ♥♥♥♥♥ keeps saddling you with difficult contracts (missions) that set you back. Also, her quarterly dividend is 10% of your company's holdings: So when I as at nearly a billion $ in the bank and many ships in my fleet, she came along and was taking nearly $200 million every quarter. The game is primarily a management game at the strategic map level. There is a 3D mini-game where you can pilot your ships in and out of the ~60 ports, each rendered on actual ports. You don’t have to do the mini game, but it costs you harbour pilot fees to dock and undock, so I usualy pilot the big ships myself and let the harbour pilot do the smaller ones, because the fees for the big shps are crazy! They could do so much more with this game though: The only online element is that the price of commodities you ship is driven by what all the other players are doing in their games (if you want true online multiplayer you need to buy TOSC: Rivals), otherwise it is a private single player experience; They could have also had a design and build your own ship element (currently you can only buy new or used predefined ship classes); They also could have had far more ports with greater variation in freight and range of commodities; I would have also like to see a 3D first person on the bridge feature to reallt challenge you in the mini-game.I have to admit that I am enjoying the management side of it as well as the gamification aspect of the quests/challenges/missions. However, I can see how after a while it will seem pointless and get boring. Maybe it would be different on a more diffilcut level, but the introductory 'easy' level is too easy, but that’s where the excelent tutorial and assistance feature sits, so that what I started with.I also have to admit that I am using Excel to help track things: I have a 4-sheet .xlsx that tracks the ports, freight, ships, routes, contracts, challenges, etc., becasue the in-game lists and tracking are not as effective at getting at ithout closing existing screens. It could have done the interface a lot better.

												Short review: I loved Ports of Call - and i played this for 7 hours straight.Long review: Nice modernised version of PoC. Not one single hickup in 7 hours, thats nice coding. And i have not visited the forums for any help whatsoever - the game is quite intuitive and you pick things up fast.At first i thought "Hey, its only a map of Europe", but after you visit each port in the Free game mode, the entire world unlocks. Like with Ports of call, there aren't enough things to buy for your money. The game designers have gone with the "Euro Truck Simulator 2" moneysink - Buildings in each town that do... errm...well, they make you feel good about yourself.Like with PoC you can command your own ships, i have done this a billion times in PoC on the Amiga and on the PC version and skipped that totally. Automatic docking fees may seem a bit high at first, but when you see how much money you make per trip it becomes small change.I really liked the ability to upgrade and somewhat specialise your ships (Cooling unit for chemicals or Anti-shake for electronics), but it would be nice to have some sort of template thing for this so you do not have to upgrade a billion ships every time you buy em. And you can take as much cargo as the ship can hold, which makes going from port to port to pick up additional cargo more essential to maximise your profits, at least early on before you get 20 mil for shipping some antique cargo containers in your Panamax ships.For a PoC clone, some things are missing - there are no icebergs and you do not save sailors for status points, this subracts from the whole "ship simulation" feel. The music is well done and the graphics are.. sufficient. Overall, this is a good game, even if you missed out on PoC you may end up playing this ship business simulator for days.

												Aside from a small number of issues or crashes, this game turned out to be exactly the game I wanted.  I have played through several 4x titles, although I had not gotten my hands on many company development or trading sims, per se, so I wasn't sure what to anticipate.  I got it as part of a bundle, not daring to hope that it would be worthwhile... but this is a completely developed game.  It is not a 60GB monster with 100 cutscenes and a VR expansion...but it is a fun game!I generally like Steam achievements, as well. 8)Pros:It is pretty; it is not clunky; the UI is quaintly graceful and not difficult to master; the options are usable and useful; the script writing and characters are humorous and likable; and the gameplay itself is enjoyable.  It is cute.  It's a cute game in which I may control thousands upon thousands in tonnage of freight in a variety of ways. 8)There is a glossary, which could be better fleshed out, but it is good to have available.I can see myself 25 years ago getting through my homework early each day so that I might play this as a reward.Cons:I've discovered at least one crash which seems to occur with some consistency, and it takes place when, steering in a harbor, I crash one of my ships too hard into something, reducing its overall condition by 7% or more.The only other thing that has stood out at all to me as a negative is the fact that once I have bought a ship, although it is easy for me to understand what category it fits into, I have not found a way to see again what *type* of ship it is.  (When I am buying the ship I can see this information, but if decide that I really do or do not want to buy another ship of that model, then I must rely on my memory alone in order to purchase or avoid that given model of ship.)If you are looking for a game in which decisions count for a lot, and in which you can enjoy a great deal of freedom to decide how you want to play it, then this might be a very good game for you.  As a company simulator, it has pleased me and I will continue to play.  TransOcean: TSC is...hobby-like.  I have put about 25 hours into the game and I have not yet touched the playmode which is not the campaign ("Challenge Mode," I think), yet I shall recommend it.  I was excited to see today that half a year ago a sequel was released.  Cool!

												I wanted to love it, but it just didn't quite work.It's a nice little game, but only a brief diversion with little replayability.  Its general mechanic of buying ships and sending them out, optimizing routes, cargoes, and fuel use to make a profit, is fun.  But it has some flaws that kill the experience.Every time you dock, you have a choice - pay a high tug fee, or dock manually. The docking mini-game is a waste of 2-3 minutes, with terrible frame rate for its looks, and people who want to play the shipping strategy don't want to play ship simulator every 30 seconds. So you generally just eat the tug costs once you can afford them.Customizing ships for certain cargoes - refrigeration for food and medicine, for instance - means almost nothing. There's no penalty for not doing it except if you get caught by customs, and that's a super rare event.There's little difficulty.  It's very, very hard, if not impossible, to lose at the game. I never even had to take out loans and contracts were super easy to complete.There's little replayability.  Once you unlock the largest ships, all you're doing is running the same routes over and over, just watching your account balance spiraling into the multiple billions.  There's nothing to achieve, and it quickly gets boring.This could be a fun game with a little more depth, a little more difficulty, and either no mini-game, or more and better ones - sort of a Sid Meier's Pirates! with cargo vessels.  As it is... it's not terrible, just a little lacklustre.

												I'm not the type who post reviews but I felt the urge to do so because I had better expectations for this game. TransOcean is becoming quite old after a couple of hours. Don't get me wrong, I am the type of gamer that can grind for hours on end, but there are so few gameplay elements within this game that it started to feel quite boring after a while. Still, this does not explain my urge to post a review for this, so why then? Because there are couple of things that, in my opinion, they should have been a must!The first and the most important missing feature is that you cannot order a custom ship. You are only able to buy pre-defined ships from the shipyard. I truly believe that it wouldn't have take that much developing time to add a couple of new menu pages + the code behind them and the result it would have definitely improve the strategy factor for the gameplay. Also the only "type" of ship is container one. Where are the oil tankers or the passenger ships? I mean, even the ore is transported in container ships? From my knowledge it is not the case. And the last major thing that bugs me is the fact that you can only take transport contracts. No possibility to purchase something that the port produces and sell it somewhere else, just transport contracts.Other nice feature addition, would have been to have ships or cargo insurance, and having some kind of simulated stock exchange. Also, some AI competition during the campaign would have been nice.About the game, decent graphics, and the ports have their own identity and you can zoom out to see the landmarks in the port, which is cool. Still, you will "park" your boat during the first transport missions as you really are low on cash, but after a while you will find yourself just using the auto-doc regardless of the costs, as you will have more than enough money to afford the cost. I also encountered some bugs, even though I did not made any effort in looking for them. One would be that while manually docking in England's port (can't remember the name now), the FPS drops quite badly if there is any ship in the port. Also it seems that there are some broken mechanics in the company contracts, after loading a save, you will get contracts that are 20+ mil in rewards, but after half an hour of gameplay, even bigger contracts rarely have rewards that pass the 6 mil barrier.All in all, I completed the campaign, I doubt I'll try the free play in the near feature, considering that I experienced a better similar game, this title will probably get lost in my library. If by any chance any developer will read this, please take an hour or so and play a 1997 game called Ocean Trader. It is a DOS game, and you will then probably understand why I cannot recommend this title.

Posted: June 26, 2015
												A great little tycoon style game.TransOcean is not a simulator; it doesn't go into much detail. The game basically just consists of loading crates on your ships and sending them from A to B. There is also a "minigame" where you can sail your own ships as they dock or leave the port.The sailing minigame will not keep you entertained for hours, but it is fun to play now and again when you buy a new ship, and it will save you some in-game money when you play it, as well as grant you some achievements.There are 5 classes of ships, all of which can have various upgrades installed, like better engines, water canons to fight back pirate attacks, or a license which allows you to transport juicy nuclear waste.The rest of the game just consists of carefully choosing contracts of what merchandise to transport where, and it's up to you to find the route planning that will be the most lucrative. You can also transport drugs or contraband for extra cash, but risk losing all if inspected by coast guards.There are also company contracts, which grant you substantial bonuses if you guarantee you will transport X amount of merchandise on a designated route in X amount of months. Fail to fulfil it and you will have to pay a big penalty.One of the most fun I have found in this game is deliberately accepting a ludicrous amount of company contracts and then having fun struggling to complete everything in time!In addition, as you level up, your antipathetic investor will throw some ridiculous contracts at you that you cannot refuse. These moments are the big highlights of the campaign.Once you have fully leveled up, there is not much end-game, so TransOcean won't keep you entertained for ever, but all in all the campaign has a good 25 hours in it.Technically it's well built, the interface is designed okay and I encountered very few bugs. The game comes with a set of elevator music tracks which I recommend you switch off from the beginnnig; then it just plays relaxing seaside soundsDefinitely one of the best tycoon style games out there.

												The business aspect of the game are superficial at best - There's no competition, no global fluctuations in the market, and all you can do is carry project cargo with container ships. Seriously, you can't establish liners services or anything; you're picking up one or two cargoes at best and essentially tramping. It's really not very complex, and the campaign is just a grind. The price of tug service doesn't make sense (It's about 50 to 1000 more than they cost in real life, seriously), and neither do the ship improvements - I have to stop a ship for two days to get a license to carry dangerous goods? Not only is firefighting gear an option, it's only available on the largest ships?If you're looking for a remotely realistic simulation of the shipping business, give it a pass.The ship simulation aspect is similarly basic... No transverse thrust on the propeller, only the larger ships have bow and stern thrusters, there's no wind or current and the ships don't have inertia. Seriously, the best way to make a dock perpendicular to the direction you started with is to speed up, then turn at the last minute and slide sideways into it, Dukes of Hazard style. Give it a pass, and be very careful when considering the new version.

												If someone is willing to spend several hours, or days, working through the various levels of achievement this game has--then see it all taken away in the space of 10 to 15 seconds--and for no apparent reason--this is the game for you!  Otherwise, STAY AWAY!This game is divided into difficulties of play:  "easy," "normal," "hard," etc.  When playing above the "easy" level this game can be very frustrating to play.  The experience is similiar to one playing a "rigged" game in the very few casinos that have them.  This game has three main characters:  the "investor;" the "assistant," and the "old captain."  The assistant is, basically, a tutorial device.  The information the "assistant" provides is useful.  The "old captain" will tell you if you did something wrong in docking at a port or sailing out of one.  The "old captain" also provides advice on how to maintain your ships.  The "investor" is a very sneeky and greedy individual.  The contract you are forced to sign with her (if playing in "normal" status or above) is so unfair that, in real life, an American court would probably rule such a contract to be void.  Without warning this "investor" is allowed to demand that you ship a list of goods to a port she has selected.  If you are unable to comply with this demand this "investor" can throw you out of the game.  Sometimes, however, this investor will let you off with a warning.The "normal," and higher, categories of this game are sub-divided into various titles--"Consignor," "Ship Boss," etc.  The player reaches these titles after completing certain tasks.  These tasks can take up to 3 to 4 hours of playing time for each title.  The BIGGEST problem with this game is the secrecy and lack of information the developers have, either, intentionally built into the game, or, the developers have no desire to make corrections to make the game rules clearer and fairer to the player.  You can be kicked-out of this game for no apparent reason.  The worse part is this game is, obviously, designed to kick you out only after several hours of play.  You may have progressed (as I did) to the third title; have 8 to 10 ships; and have a balance of 130 million Euros.  Then, for no understandable reason, the calendar starts spinning wildly (and NOT responding to the "pause game" or "slow down" keys) and your balance, likewise, starts wildly dropping.  After about 10 to 15 seconds you get a message that your company is bankrupt--thus, you've been thrown out of the game.  Of course, you always have the option to start a new game--with no credit or assets from the game you just got thrown out of!

												"Great game", it's that simple. You start your adventure with a feeder, and every minutes you are planning in your mind which trade route to choose and where to stem your bunker with most economical price. Now you are getting more and more money, and expanding your fleet with regional traders, and eventually going up to those beatiful ladies - PPMX, NPMX and Ultra-Large Container Vessel. Oh! Now you are ready for a round-the-world service. Further to ocean trading, you can always berth / unberth the vessel on your own, and I would say this is the most interesting element of this game. The difficulties...well, I guess it's hard to name your ships. With the fleet getting ever larger, I decide to simply pick a real world Liner Operator and name all my ships as per their's. As I said, it's a great game. But there are always ways to further enhance the gaming experience:-1. Canal passage. It would be great if I have to pay my canal due for passage,  sail my ship through the Suez, or may be have to anchor my ship off Cristobal a day or two due to canal congestion.2. Larger scale of map when docking/undocking my ship. It's quite often I find it difficult to expect where will I berth my lady until I see it. And if possible, it would be great to have a "longer" sailing option before berthing/after unberthing.3. Some more "small contracts" - I find it hard to believe I am shipping some thousands TEU of Radioactive Materials to Hong Kong, or loads of weapons ex. US/Canada to Cuba...4. More realistic color of the Equipments (i.e. containers) - The Equipments are just too sharp and colorful.5. Players can draw the company logo in-game, and decide where to put the Operator's Color on the ship's hull.6. More real world events - e.g.: Pay for ice-breaker when approaching Gulf of St. Lawrence, stowaways sneaked onboard at West/South African countries, economic changes that affect the global bunker price SERIOUSLY...etc.The trading mode is realistic only if the game is for General Cargo Carriers. For Container vessels, it appears more "real world" if we are to plan and maintain service routes across the globe...well may be it's just me thinking of this only.If you like ships, go for it. 												"Great game", it's that simple. You start your adventure with a feeder, and every minutes you are planning in your mind which trade route to choose and where to stem your bunker with most economical price. Now you are getting more and more money, and expanding your fleet with regional traders, and eventually going up to those beatiful ladies - PPMX, NPMX and Ultra-Large Container Vessel. Oh! Now you are ready for a round-the-world service. Further to ocean trading, you can always berth / unberth the vessel on your own, and I would say this is the most interesting element of this game. The difficulties...well, I guess it's hard to name your ships. With the fleet getting ever larger, I decide to simply pick a real world Liner Operator and name all my ships as per their's. As I said, it's a great game. But there are always ways to further enhance the gaming experience:-1. Canal passage. It would be great if I have to pay my canal due for passage,  sail my ship through the Suez, or may be have to anchor my ship off Cristobal a day or two due to canal congestion.2. Larger scale of map when docking/undocking my ship. It's quite often I find it difficult to expect where will I berth my lady until I see it. And if possible, it would be great to have a "longer" sailing option before berthing/after unberthing.3. Some more "small contracts" - I find it hard to believe I am shipping some thousands TEU of Radioactive Materials to Hong Kong, or loads of weapons ex. US/Canada to Cuba...4. More realistic color of the Equipments (i.e. containers) - The Equipments are just too sharp and colorful.5. Players can draw the company logo in-game, and decide where to put the Operator's Color on the ship's hull.6. More real world events - e.g.: Pay for ice-breaker when approaching Gulf of St. Lawrence, stowaways sneaked onboard at West/South African countries, economic changes that affect the global bunker price SERIOUSLY...etc.The trading mode is realistic only if the game is for General Cargo Carriers. For Container vessels, it appears more "real world" if we are to plan and maintain service routes across the globe...well may be it's just me thinking of this only.If you like ships, go for it. If you like trading game, go for it. If you want to sail a vessel, go for it. There's no much choice where you can sail vessels from a 480TEU feeder to a ULCV with bow/stern thrusters.

												I don't normally post  reviews, but I felt this title worth a mention.  There have been a lot of half-hearted continental simulations released recently and this definately doesn't fall in to that category!Ok, graphically, the "driving sim" aspect of this title could be better... It's a little 2D feeling and has a tendancy to stutter when you go for maximum speed, but it's passable most of the time.Having said that, this is, in my option, a solid micro-management sim.  You have good control over the day-to-day running of your shipping company, but can also comfortably out-source many of the more mundane tasks (albeit at a sigificant cost).Personally, I'm ok with that... I think it should be a significant expense in the early days to outsource any substantial portion of your management role in these kind of titles.After 6 and a half hours (or so) of play I can tell you the following:POSITIVES:* Storyline is ok, driven by solid tutorials... They are progressive and detailed enough to point you in the right direction without being condecending.* Graphics are better than anything else I have come across in this specific genre.* Controls are pretty instictive and as expected - camera controlled from mouse and helful auto-centering.* Sound - I've seen some negative postings, but, in general, I've been pretty impressed.  Music gets a little repetative in the world view as you spend a lot of time there, but each port is individualised and, overall, it's a pretty calming, uninvasive soundtrack.* Overall gameplay is going to keep genre fans entertained for some time... There's certainly enough variables to grab attention, but cost and development route are inevitable and welcome challenges!NEGATIVES:* It seemed to take an excessive amount of time to pass the first few story objectives. I imagine this is because this is many designed to be a "sandbox" title, but I'm hoping greater structure will be added in time.* On the subject of additions, the are many noteworthy european shipping ports which are currently missing... Let's hope this is remedied in any future updates!!!All in all, a worthwhile spend... Enjoy!!!!!!

												**Contains game details to make points, so beware spoilers.**Game was interesting and had a lot of good bits, but was too shallow overall. There's no real company progress, just meet a few requirements and you unlock the next bigger ship; rinse and repeat. They did a job creating an investor that you'll grow a seething hatred for as she continues to leech your funds ever quarter whilst creating contracts that you can't complete without breaking the law [get product X from city Y; this city only allows the tiniest ships to dock at it, and you need an upgrade to lawfully carry product X - an upgrade that the tiniest ship cannot get]. The end game requires building up a very large amount of spare cash to free yourself from the investor; the amount is 2x the company's late-game value, so if you're punished if you like to have some spare cash on hand. Building a large fleet - which is required to buy out the company - generates a ton of busywork, as there's no sort of automation available. I really enjoy sim-management games, but this one punishes you unless you grind towards great profits; mainly, trying to keep your head above water as Ms. BS gouges you for 10% of your value every quarter [her name is Ms. Blythe-Smith, but maybe the initials were chosen intentionally]. I think I would have enjoyed TransOcean much more if it focused on managing the company rather than managing the minutia.The ability to manually dock and cast off is fun, but it gets tedious considering how many shipping runs you must make; I think if you did every maneuver manually it'd about triple the amount of time played, and eventually feels a bit like busy work [the game forces you to do some maneuvers later game in order to progress, which may help some discover this bit they've been missing out on, but it also feels forced for those that want to focus on the management aspect].It looks like a TO2 is in progress, and I'll probably check it out based on how it looks and the price. TO isn't a bad game, and I was on the fence about giving a 'No' recommendation. I'd probably give it a 7/10 overall - there are just many better games in genre to spend time on, especially ones that have better replay value.

												When I first read about TransOcean Shipping, I added it to my wishlist and followed it closely for several months. The mixed reviews made me skeptical about buying it, but as I'd been starved for a good business simulation, decided to take the gamble - and I'm pleased I did!In the game you play the founder of a shipping company, whom takes on an investor to fund his company. Starting off with one small 'Feeder' ship, you have to accept contracts and weigh decisions over speed/fuel consumption to ensure that deliveries are made on time. The campaign aspect of the game provides extra challenge, allowing you to unlock larger vessels as you progress in rank and prestige, whilst constantly trying to ensure you have enough money to provide the investor her regular payments.Ships can be docked and cast off manually, which offers you the chance to control your ship if you'd rather avoid paying the tug fees (automatic docking/cast off) in ports. This can provide a nice little break from the 'main map' game screen, which is where you'll spend most of your time. Eventually you'll have a fleet of different sized ships, and will need to juggle factors of tight deadlines, contract penalties and the various ship sizes permitted to dock in certain ports etc. Despite the fact that you spend so much time staring at the map screen, the challenge and reward of juggling everything around is thoroughly entertaining. It's a game that doesn't require too much thought and that you can play casually. I personally found the game addictive, but I appreciate that it won't appeal to everyone - I'm sure many would find the lack of variation a little tiresome/boring. If you're unsure whether you'd enjoy this game, do what I did and check a gameplay video online. There are many to watch, and will give you an accurate idea of how this game plays.

												If you liked Port of Call for DOS or Amiga as well as it was back in the day, here is a modern reincarnation.While the 3D view perhaps still has some issues, seeing as you can't move the camera as freely as you like to do, it still breathes life into an old game from the 90s.While it is a ship tycoon game, and not much of a Ship driving simulator (And thank god for that) it is great fun to "manage" your company.One difference from Port of Call is that you now have to upgrade your ships to ship certain cargos, or to increase a ship's performance.The bad side of this game is that there are some bugs in the user interface that can make you a little confused.For an example after some time in game, when selecting cargo contracts for your ship, the checkmark to show that you have selected that contract disappears, it is still selected, so if you hit "Accept contracts" they will show up for confirmation.Then during the campaign you will also feel like killing your second "investor" and here the devs would do the world a great favor by introducing an "Arrange accident" button for that "investor"The investor has a tendency to pass out contracts when you least want it, and forcing you to abandon contracts you are working on and scramble to fullfill the contract or face an ONGOING penalty until fulfilled.Mark my words when I say ONGOING, it means that you lose millions until you get it fulfilled, and this get so frustrating at times, that you really wish you could get rid of the investor, by ANY MEANS NECESSARY.Past this, this game is worth the money it costs IF and only IF you liked Port of Call from the DOS era.If not, I recommend you try the old DOS title first to see if a shipping tycoon game is something for you, and then consider this title.Word of note, this game is now EOL (End Of Life) with no more patches coming, and it still has a few bugs, including one crashing bug, plus one bug that can get you stuck, and forced to either kill the process or get into the options menu to fix it.But the worst bug that can wreck you, it is very possible to get the game stuck in fast forward mode, meaning you will have ships arriving in port, and waiting for your confirmation to unload, but time will still keep passing at a record rate, causing delayed arrivals, and thus steep penalty fees.

												Heavy on pretty looks, feather-light on gameplay.So, Thumbs up for the pretty graphics of the docking-minigame.Everything else can be summarized in a few words:Tedious gameplay, very-very shallow realism, virtually non-existent long-term motivation, and full of inaccuracies.. Also I find the amount of highly unrealistic and extremely repetitive micro-management very boring. A true motivation killer.All this is played through a "management" interface, which does not assist one jot in managing a multi-vessel fleet. On the contrary.This game should be tagged "shallow simulation of a shallow trade-simulation". The docking-minigame likewise cannot be called a simulation, as is has nothing in common with handling a large vessel...in fact, not even of that of a 30ft sailboat. However, without it, this game would not even have the pretty graphics.  Nice for an average 12 year old.Most definitely not a title for enthusiats of trade and management sims. If you are looking for an interlectual challenge and some insights into the "real" world of cargo shipping, and big scale logistics, look elsewhere.The proposed features for the announced version 2 of this title, do not seem to address these issues. Rather, it seems to take the existing version and expands it into a multiplayer version. A great pity, because the idea is great. There is no in-depth simulation of this genre to my knowledge...and there still isn't...and by the looks of it, version 2 won't change that. In my opinion, the trading and management functions and interfaces require extensive improvements, before this title deserves to be called an exciting game and a simulation.I give 10 out of 10 for the idea, and a 5 out of 10 for execution.All in all, in my view, yet another disappointment, and most definitely not worth the cost. There are more enjoyable apps in the itunes appstore.

												**Contains game details to make points, so beware spoilers.**Game was interesting and had a lot of good bits, but was too shallow overall. There's no real company progress, just meet a few requirements and you unlock the next bigger ship; rinse and repeat. They did a job creating an investor that you'll grow a seething hatred for as she continues to leech your funds ever quarter whilst creating contracts that you can't complete without breaking the law [get product X from city Y; this city only allows the tiniest ships to dock at it, and you need an upgrade to lawfully carry product X - an upgrade that the tiniest ship cannot get]. The end game requires building up a very large amount of spare cash to free yourself from the investor; the amount is 2x the company's late-game value, so if you're punished if you like to have some spare cash on hand. Building a large fleet - which is required to buy out the company - generates a ton of busywork, as there's no sort of automation available. I really enjoy sim-management games, but this one punishes you unless you grind towards great profits; mainly, trying to keep your head above water as Ms. BS gouges you for 10% of your value every quarter [her name is Ms. Blythe-Smith, but maybe the initials were chosen intentionally]. I think I would have enjoyed TransOcean much more if it focused on managing the company rather than managing the minutia.The ability to manually dock and cast off is fun, but it gets tedious considering how many shipping runs you must make; I think if you did every maneuver manually it'd about triple the amount of time played, and eventually feels a bit like busy work [the game forces you to do some maneuvers later game in order to progress, which may help some discover this bit they've been missing out on, but it also feels forced for those that want to focus on the management aspect].It looks like a TO2 is in progress, and I'll probably check it out based on how it looks and the price. TO isn't a bad game, and I was on the fence about giving a 'No' recommendation. I'd probably give it a 7/10 overall - there are just many better games in genre to spend time on, especially ones that have better replay value.

												TransOcean has some good points - there is a measure of strategy involved, with picking different cargoes and so on for the best profit.However, the negative aspects of the game outweigh the positive ones.Being double-charged for fuel and repair costs stands at the top of the list, in my view. When you arrive in a port, the estimated costs for fuel and any repairs are deducted from your profits for that trip. This is particularly tiresome when you arrive in a port that has expensive fuel prices, as you lose more.You still have to refuel and repair the ship though, paying for that separately.The investor you have to deal with is another aspect. Whilst she is entitled to her share of profits every quarter, the inane tasks that she forces on you from time to time are ridiculous.On at least two occasions, you are required to transport items that the feeder ships are not designed for - and if you can't complete the entire task, you face an enormous penalty. The tasks do add yet another level of strategy to the game, but they should be relevant to the ships you have at the time.Since the developers have still not seen fit to change this, or improve the game at all, then I cannot recommend TransOcean.
